abstract: “I got a heightened sense at a young age of what is right and what it is wrong,” said Andrew Prozes, chief executive, LexisNexis Group.
snippet: “I got a heightened sense at a young age of what is right and what it is wrong,” said Andrew Prozes, chief executive, LexisNexis Group.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my wife’s very close childhood friends is Bo Jones, publisher of The Washington Post. I recently found myself at dinner with him, Ben Bradlee, Sally Quinn and Jim Lehrer at a restaurant in Biarritz, France. Jim Lehrer asked us all a monumental question. He asked us what we missed most from our childhood. Everyone went through their story of how they missed something. I ended up being the last one to say something. The reality was I didn’t have anything I missed from my childhood. We were pretty poor. We didn’t even have inside plumbing until I was 17. That pretty much shut up everyone who was around the table.

abstract: AirTran Holdings, the discount airline company, is planning to raise its hostile bid for the Midwest Air Group a third time, to $15 a share, people briefed on the offer said Sunday night. The company plans to announce the new bid Monday, these people said.

abstract: AT&T said on Sunday that it was in negotiations to buy a major stake in Italy’s largest telecommunications company, Telecom Italia. The proposal, which expires at the end of April, would give AT&T a one-third stake in Telecom Italia’s holding company, Olimpia, but only if a Mexican wireless company America Movil buys an equal stake. AT&T, based in San Antonio, is an 8 percent owner of America Movil.

AT&T, based in San Antonio, is an 8 percent owner of America Movil.

headline.main: AT&T Weighs Bid for Italian Telecom Company Stake

abstract: California-based Xponent Photonics raised $23 million in a series 3 round with American River Ventures leading the charge. American River Ventures put up a $5 million stake while Xponent’s previous investors, including El Dorado Ventures, Arcturus Capital and the Samsung Group put up the rest. Xponent makes fast, small semiconductor chips using new optical technology.

abstract: SKS Microfinance, a fast-growing Indian company that provides financing for entrepeneurs, has received an $11.5 million injection with Sequoia Capital putting up most of the funds. Sequoia, which has made such savvy previous investments as those in Google, Yahoo and YouTube, was joined in the round by Unitus Equity Fund, Vinod Khosla, Ravi Reddy, Odyssey Capital and prior investor Sidbi.

abstract: A new breed of wealthy investor is changing the way startups raise capital. Business Week took a look at a startup, Jaxtr, which makes software for routing calls from blogs to cell phones, and the unusual arrangement it made for its first round of financing.

abstract: The Carlyle Group announced on Friday that it would invest $80 million for a 49 percent stake in China’s Yangzhou Chengde Steel Tube Company. Yangzhou Chengde makes large-diameter seamless steel pipes and Carlyle’s investment will help the company to expand its business both domestically and abroad. The investment comes from Carlyle Asia Partners II, a $1.8 billion fund that makes control and strategic minority investments in Asia outside Japan.

abstract: India’s Tata Power announced this weekend that it is planning to take a 30 percent stake in coal mines owned by the Indonesian energy giant PT Bumi Resources for about $1.3 billion. Although Bumi failed to raise $3.2 billion through a share sale last year, there were at least six bidders vying for the coal companies this time around.

Allco Equity Partners, which has a 17.3 percent stake in Veda, has agreed to support the deal subject to a significant change in market conditions and in the absence of a superior offer, said Reuters.

abstract: Barclays is planning to make cost cuts of more than 3 billion pounds in its proposed merger with ABN Amro, the Dutch bank. The move will likely lead to the loss of hundreds of jobs at ABN Amro’s investment banking operations in London, the Telegraph reported.

Altadis, a Franco-Spanish tobacco group, is being courted by a number of private equity groups, a development that is thought to be behind the board’s decision to reject Imperial’s bid.

abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy, the rightwing candidate in the French presidential race, joined the growing chorus of European voices criticizing hedge funds, the Financial Times reported Monday. Speaking at a television debate on Sunday, Mr. Sarkozy attacked what he called speculative capitalism, citing hedge funds in particular: “these aggressive funds … that buy up a company, sell it off in pieces, sack 25 per cent of the staff in the meantime, collect 25 per cent profit and create zero wealth.” He added: “I don’t want a speculative capitalism. I want a capitalism that creates riches.”
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Sarkozy, the rightwing candidate in the French presidential race, joined the growing chorus of European voices criticizing hedge funds, the Financial Times reported Monday. Speaking at a television debate on Sunday, Mr. Sarkozy attacked what he called speculative capitalism, citing hedge funds in particular: “these aggressive funds … that buy up a company, sell it off in pieces, sack 25 per cent of the staff in the meantime, collect 25 per cent profit and create zero wealth.” He added: “I don’t want a speculative capitalism. I want a capitalism that creates riches.”

headline.main: France’s Sarkozy Attacks Hedge Funds as ‘Speculative Capital’

abstract: Though Community Health Systems could soon boast of becoming the nation’s largest publicly traded hospital chain when it closes its $5.1 billion offer for Triad Hospitals, TheStreet.com says that the company may soon regret it. To achieve that lofty post, the site’s Melissa Davis writes, the efficiency-minded Community is buying a hospital chain known for making generous investments to lure patients in competitive markets.

abstract: The Carlyle Group is expected to announce on Monday the hiring of Coca-Cola‘s most senior executive in Asia to spearhead regional investments across consumer-related businesses. The recruitment of the executive, Patrick Siewert, Coca-Cola’s chief operating officer for Asia-Pacific, is the second such hiring in recent weeks by the buyout firm and highlights the maturing of private equity in Asia.

abstract: Showing a rare flash of humor, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued a press release on executive pay disclosure quoting spokeswoman “April Fuhrst” and economist “Anita Moore-Profit.” In the release, the top market regulator in the United States sets out new rules on corproate pay and perks that Ms. Fuhrst said would “reveal a treasure trove of titillating information,” The Financial Times reported.

abstract: Xerox said on Monday it would acquire the office technology products provider Global Imaging Systems for $1.5 billion to expand its reach in the small and mid-sized business markets. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., said the deal values Global Imaging at $29 a share, a premium of almost a 50 percent to its closing price Friday of $19.50. Global Imaging shares rose more than 46 percent in pre-market trade.

abstract: Sam Zell, the flamboyant Chicago real estate tycoon, who has never run a newspaper, has won the battle of the billionaires for Tribune, which said it accepted his $8.2 billion takeover offer after he matched a bid from Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad.

abstract: TXU said on Monday that it has not received a competing bid to the $32 billion takeover offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group, and its financial advisers do not expect it to receive one. The power company, which agreed in February to the buyout, said it had signed confidentiality agreements with nine groups as part of the 50 day “go-shop” agreement with its buyers allowing it to pursue alternative transactions.
lead_paragraph: TXU said on Monday that it has not received a competing bid to the $32 billion takeover offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group, and its financial advisers do not expect it to receive one. headline.main: TXU Does Not Expect Other Suitors

abstract: Three-quarters of loans to junk-rated companies in the United States are now provided by hedge funds and other non-banks, according to a new report on the leveraged loan market. The Financial Times said that the study highlights the speed with which non-traditional investors are taking over from banks as lenders and changing the way loans are made and traded – a trend that has taken hold in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Three-quarters of loans to junk-rated companies in the United States are now provided by hedge funds and other non-banks, according to a new report on the leveraged loan market. The Financial Times said that the study highlights the speed with which non-traditional investors are taking over from banks as lenders and changing the way loans are made and traded – a trend that has taken hold in Europe.

headline.main: Hedge Funds Now Dominate Junk-Grade Lenders, Study Finds

abstract: First Data, one of the nation’s largest credit-card processing companies, said early Monday it had agreed to be acquired for $29 billion by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. The transaction is among the 10 largest buyouts ever. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $34 a share in cash for First Data, which controls the STAR payment network. The sale price represents a 26 percent premium to First Data’s closing share price Friday.
lead_paragraph: First Data, one of the nation’s largest credit-card processing companies, said early Monday it had agreed to be acquired for $29 billion by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. The transaction is among the 10 largest buyouts ever. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $34 a share in cash for First Data, which controls the STAR payment network. The sale price represents a 26 percent premium to First Data’s closing share price Friday.

headline.main: Kohlberg Kravis to Buy First Data in $29 Billion Deal

abstract: Dubai Aerospace will buy Standard Aero Holdings and Piedmont/Hawthorne Holdings from the Carlyle Group for $1.8 billion, Standard Aero said on Monday in a regulatory filing. It said $1.034 billion of the total purchase price will be allocated to the purchase of Standard Aero.
lead_paragraph: Dubai Aerospace will buy Standard Aero Holdings and Piedmont/Hawthorne Holdings from the Carlyle Group for $1.8 billion, Standard Aero said on Monday in a regulatory filing. It said $1.034 billion of the total purchase price will be allocated to the purchase of Standard Aero.

headline.main: Dubai Aerospace Announces Deal for 2 Carlyle Companies

abstract: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.
lead_paragraph: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.

headline.main: Web Measurement Firm ComScore to Go Public

abstract: Once a highflier in the booming market for making risky mortgage loans, New Century Financial tumbled to earth Monday as it filed for bankruptcy. abstract: Vneshtorgbank, Russia’s second-biggest bank, could raise up to $6 billion when it makes its debut share offering with listings in Moscow and London next month. The state-owned bank plans to come to the market with an offering of 22 to 23 percent of its shares in May. Russia’s Economic Development and Trade Minister, German Gref, has said the bank could raise between $3.5 billion and $4.6 billion, while the bank has indicated it wants to raise between $4 billion and $6 billion.
lead_paragraph: Vneshtorgbank, Russia’s second-biggest bank, could raise up to $6 billion when it makes its debut share offering with listings in Moscow and London next month. The state-owned bank plans to come to the market with an offering of 22 to 23 percent of its shares in May. abstract: A boss who won’t live near the office may not make many friends.

lead_paragraph: In the age of the imperial chief executive, where a history of failure does not keep someone from getting another top job, some bosses think they should not be forced to actually live in the area where the company is located. They see no reason why their families should be uprooted.

headline.main: Why Live Near the Office?

abstract: Record profits, and payroll, on Wall Street

lead_paragraph: A Wall Street trade group put out combined profit statistics for the industry today, and they are impressive. The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association says securities firms had combined pretax profits last year of $33.1 billion, up 88 percent from the prior year, and finally breaking the record they set in 2000 of $31.6 billion.

abstract: An auditor flees sub-prime lenders

lead_paragraph: Grant Thornton, the auditing firm, might have had the belated realization last week that auditing a subprime lender could almost be as risky as financing one. In any case, letters dated Tuesday, March 27 and disclosed today announced that the firm was resigning as auditor of Fremont General and Accredited Home Lenders, two troubled lenders.

headline.main: A ‘Klong’ at Grant Thornton

lead_paragraph: MADRID, April 2  The German energy giant E.On on Monday withdrew its offer of 42.4 billion euros ($56.6 billion) for the Spanish utility Endesa in exchange for a promise from rival bidders to sell it part of Endesa’s assets, ending one of Europe’s most arcane takeover battles.

abstract: Vehicle sales fell for a 21st straight month, led by Nissan and Toyota, capping their worst business year in three decades. Sales of cars, trucks and buses, excluding minicars, fell 12.6 percent, to 487,738 vehicles in March from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. Nissan’s sales fell 16 percent, while Toyota’s dropped 12 percent. Sales of vehicles excluding minicars dropped 8.3 percent, to 3.59 million units, the lowest level in 29 years, in the 12 months ended March 31.

abstract: Wesfarmers, Australia’s biggest home-improvement retailer, said it had bought an 11.3 percent stake in the Coles Group, the country’s second-biggest retailer, and is seeking talks with the company. Wesfarmers paid 16.47 Australian dollars ($13.40) a share for its stake, information from the Australian Stock Exchange shows, valuing Coles at 19.7 billion Australian dollars, or $16 billion. Coles, Australia’s second-biggest retailer, put itself up for sale in February, after saying it would not meet profit forecasts that had been cited to reject a bid of 18.2 billion Australian dollars by the private equity firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

abstract: AIR TAXIS ADVANCE DayJet, a Florida-based company, took delivery of three Eclipse 500 very light jets on Saturday as it geared up to start air taxi service by the summer. With 239 orders for the $1.5 million jets, DayJet is Eclipse’s largest customer. DayJet plans to begin its on-demand service on routes of 300 to 600 miles in Florida, and expand later throughout the Southeast, using regional and community airports rather than major commercial airports. Eclipse, with more than 2,500 orders for its 500 model, is one of more than half a dozen manufacturers making very light jets. About 5,000 of the new planes will be operating within 10 years, the Federal Aviation Administration has said.
snippet: AIR TAXIS ADVANCE DayJet, a Florida-based company, took delivery of three Eclipse 500 very light jets on Saturday as it geared up to start air taxi service by the summer. With 239 orders for the $1.5 million jets, DayJet is Eclipse’s largest custo...
lead_paragraph: AIR TAXIS ADVANCE  DayJet, a Florida-based company, took delivery of three Eclipse 500 very light jets on Saturday as it geared up to start air taxi service by the summer. With 239 orders for the $1.5 million jets, DayJet is Eclipse’s largest customer. DayJet plans to begin its on-demand service on routes of 300 to 600 miles in Florida, and expand later throughout the Southeast, using regional and community airports rather than major commercial airports. Eclipse, with more than 2,500 orders for its 500 model, is one of more than half a dozen manufacturers making very light jets. About 5,000 of the new planes will be operating within 10 years, the Federal Aviation Administration has said.

headline.main: Memo Pad

abstract: Members of the Federal Trade Commission look likely to try and block the $1.13 billion acquisition of Giant Industries by Western Refining. Although Giant’s shareholders approved the purchase more than a month ago, a government lawyer has said that the April 10 vote is expected to spark a second legal fight to stop a deal under its review. In March, the commission voted to halt a merger between two nonresidential natural gas suppliers in Pittsburgh, Equitable Resources and the Peoples Natural Gas Company. The deal is pending.

abstract: Russian billionaire Alexey Mordashov is set to receive a $324 million dividend from his steel company Severstal. With his worth estimated at $8.5 billion, Mr. Mordashov was recently ranked Russia’s seventh richest man by Forbes magazine. Although pre-tax profits at Severstal fell to $1.75 billion for 2006, Mr. Mordashov said the company’s outlook for 2007 was positive. He added: “We will continue to drive value through strong organic growth and a disciplined approach to M&A.”

abstract: A government-appointed panel of antitrust experts has recommended the repeal of a 1930s-era antitrust law designed to protect small retailers, Reuters said. The commission has been meeting to deliberate various antitrust laws, including the Sherman Act and the Robinson-Patman Act, to see whether they were in line with the modern economy. The suggested repeal of the latter was the biggest change recommended by the commission. The Robinson-Patman Act bars suppliers from engaging in anticompetitive price discrimination.
lead_paragraph: A government-appointed panel of antitrust experts has recommended the repeal of a 1930s-era antitrust law designed to protect small retailers, Reuters said. headline.main: Commission Suggests Repeal of 1930s Antitrust Law

abstract: Shares of Accredited Home Lenders Holding, a subprime mortgage lender, rose before the opening bell Tuesday after it said late on Monday that it had closed a loan from Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund, to increase liquidity. In exchange for a five-year, $230 million term loan facility from Farallon, Accredited will give the hedge fund warrants to acquire about 3.23 million shares at an exercise price of $10 a share.

abstract: Tribune‘s decision to use an employee stock ownership plan to help fund its sale to the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell has obvious benefits — most notably tax breaks — but also comes with some big risks, analysts said Monday. abstract: The Carmel Group, the influential research firm whose analysis helped kill the 2003 merger of EchoStar and DirecTV, will release a new report Tuesday that outlines the strongest arguments yet against merging satellite radio companies Sirius and XM, The New York Post reported. Sponsored by the National Association of Broadcasters, which has already come out against the deal, the 11-page independent white paper includes a point-by-point rebuttal to the six main arguments put forth by Sirius and XM in favor of a merger.

abstract: The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group agreed to buy the British wireless network division of National Grid for £2.5 billion ($4.93 billion) and combine the unit with its Arqiva broadcast business. National Grid, owner of the power and gas networks in Britain, said National Grid’s wireless unit had access to more than 14,500 communication sites in England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales. The unit, based in Warwick, England, owns more than 2,500 sites and has contracts with its parent for access to electricity transmission towers, National Grid said. Arqiva, based in Hampshire, England, offers networking services to broadcasters and mobile phone companies including the Vodafone Group, Telefónica, O2 and Orange of France Télécom. Macquarie is based in Sydney, Australia.

abstract: CSL, an Australian drug maker, asked for quick approval of a seasonal flu vaccine in the United States, where health officials have been battling shortages by encouraging new suppliers. CSL is seeking priority review, which could gain clearance for the shots for people 18 and older by Sept. 30, said Paul Perreault, an executive vice president at the company’s CSL Biotherapies unit.. The application is the first attempt by CSL, which has made the flu vaccine since 1962, to sell shots in the United States, Mr. Perreault said.

abstract: The Hershey Company said it was forming a joint venture in India with Godrej Beverages and Foods to manufacture and sell confections, snacks and beverages. Hershey said it would invest $60 million and take a 51 percent stake in the venture, which will be called Godrej Hershey. The rest of the venture will be held by Godrej Industries, a privately held conglomerate that is the parent company of Godrej Beverages. Through the venture, Hershey, based in Hershey, Pa., will obtain access to Godrej’s two factories and 1.6 million retail outlets. Godrej Beverages, which makes juices, soy milk and cooking oils, has annual sales of $70 million. Richard H. Lenny, Hershey’s chief executive, above, called the deal a significant step in Hershey’s global growth strategy. Production is expected to start in 2008.

abstract: Comcast, the nation’s largest cable operator, said Tuesday that it was buying a small New Jersey cable operator for $483 million. Analysts said the price was high in light of the number of subscribers but understandable given the customers’ affluence. The operator being acquired, Patriot Media and Communications, serves 81,000 video subscribers in central New Jersey, many of them in upscale neighborhoods that fit in with Comcast’s service area.

abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s flagship hedge fund, Global Alpha, lost 5.7 percent in February, hurt by positions in stocks, global bonds and currencies including the Japanese yen. The decline left the $10 billion fund down 2 percent for the year through Feb. 28, according to a monthly update sent to investors. That compared with an average gain of 1.9 percent for hedge funds worldwide, according to data compiled by Hedge Fund Research in Chicago.

abstract: The Bank of America said Tuesday that Peter Scaturro, the chief executive of U.S. Trust, will not join the bank as originally planned when the two companies combine later this year. Mr. Scaturro, 47, will step down from U.S. Trust before the transaction is completed, a Bank of America spokeswoman said, declining to comment on the reason for his departure. Mr. Scaturro had been expected to become head of Bank of America’s private-banking business after it purchased U.S. Trust from Charles Schwab.

abstract: It may have been spurned once, but Kohlberg Kravis Roberts hasn’t given up on Australia’s Coles yet. abstract: A unit of Siemens, the biggest engineering company in Europe, sued Saint-Gobain Ceramics and Plastics, contending infringement of a patent for a radiation detector that is used in medical diagnostic scanners. Siemens Medical Solutions USA said the United States unit of Saint-Gobain, a European building materials supplier, was wrongly using the technology in marketing PreLude 420 crystals for scanners that produce images from radioactive materials injected into the body to detect diseases like cancer. The suit was filed in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del. Siemens is based in Germany and Saint-Gobain is based in France.

headline.print_headline: Shell Expects Full Output From Nigeria

abstract: Google agreed to make it easier to remove offensive content posted on its Orkut social-networking site, heeding requests from prosecutors in Brazil. Google will set up a page on Orkut where prosecutors will send requests to remove content, the Rio de Janeiro state prosecutor’s office said. In Brazil, where Orkut is the most-used social networking site, prosecutors complained last year that the company was taking too long to comply with their demands to eliminate some material on the site. Google, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had added workers to review reports of offensive or illegal content, along with special tools for law enforcement to expedite reviews.

abstract: The Lundin Mining Corporation, a Canadian mining company operating in Europe, said it had agreed to acquire Rio Narcea Gold Mines for 993 million Canadian dollars ($858 million) to take advantage of record nickel prices. Lundin offered 5 Canadian dollars for each share of Rio Narcea, 3.7 percent higher than its closing price on Tuesday, and 1.03 Canadian dollars per warrant, Colin Benner, the vice chairman of Lundin, said in a conference call. The company plans to increase Rio Narcea’s nickel and copper operation in southern Spain and might sell its gold mine in Mauritania, it said. Rio Narcea is based in Toronto, and Lundin is based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

abstract: The health care company Roche Holding agreed to buy BioVeris for $600 million to expand its medical testing business. The move strengthens Roche’s position in diagnostics, where it is already a global leader. BioVeris said it had agreed to be acquired for $21.50 a share, a 58 percent premium to Tuesday’s closing price of $13.60. The purchase will allow Roche to expand its immunochemistry business from human diagnostics into segments like life science research, patient self-testing, veterinary testing, drug discovery, drug development and clinical trials.

The move strengthens Roche’s position in diagnostics, where it is already a global leader. BioVeris said it had agreed to be acquired for $21.50 a share, a 58 percent premium to Tuesday’s closing price of $13.60. The purchase will allow Roche to expand its immunochemistry business from human diagnostics into segments like life science research, patient self-testing, veterinary testing, drug discovery, drug development and clinical trials.

headline.main: Roche Strikes $600 Million Deal for BioVeris

abstract: Software AG of Germany said Thursday it would acquire webMethods, a Nasdaq-traded maker of application integration software, for $546 million. At $9.15 per share, the offer is nearly 26 percent more than webMethods’ closing share price on Wednesday. abstract: Critics of The New York Times Company‘s corporate governance have gained a powerful ally. Institutional Shareholder Services, a proxy advisory firm, on Thursday advised the media company’s shareholders to withhold their votes for directors seeking re-election in order to send a “strong message” that changes are needed. The firm’s recommendation came less than three weeks before the Times’s annual shareholder meeting, which is likely to be a contentious affair. A fund managed by Morgan Stanley has been pressuring the Times Company to dissolve the two-tiered stock structure that gives voting control to the Sulzberger family, something the Times has said it will not do.

headline.main: Proxy Firm Adds to Pressure on Times Company

abstract: Shares in Puma Rudolf Dassler Sport surged nearly 10 percent on Thursday as speculation mounted that PPR, the French luxury goods conglomerate, would launch a bid for the German sportswear maker. “There are rumors in the market that Pinault Printemps could make an offer for Puma next week,” an unnamed trader told Reuters. Puma shares rose 9.5 percent by mid-afternoon trading in Germany Tuesday, far outpacing that country’s mid-cap stock index, up 0.2 percent. The trading volume of Puma shares exceeded the three-month average by more than six times.

abstract: Software, a software maker, agreed to buy webMethods of the United States for $546 million in cash to add networking software to its product line and more than double its customer numbers in North America. abstract: Unusual trading activity before last week’s buyout of First Data has reignited concerns about insider trading. Now, the First Data trades, and allegations of insider trading before this year’s $45 billion TXU buyout, are giving the issue new attention.

abstract: Citigroup has agreed to buy Taiwan’s Bank of Overseas Chinese for 14.1 billion Taiwan dollars ($426 million) amid growing foreign interest in Taiwan’s undervalued banking sector. Citigroup will acquire 100 percent of the company in the all-cash deal, a board member, Weng Chien, told Reuters. Under terms of the deal, Citigroup will pay 11.80 Taiwan dollars per share, the companies said in a statement. The acquisition will increase Citigroup’s Taiwan-based assets to $22.8 billion.

abstract: In many multibillion-dollar deals, conflicts of interest are an unavoidable way of life. The multiple roles that Merrill Lynch and Citigroup played in the $8.2 billion sale of Tribune — advising the company in the sale process as well as providing financing to the winning bidder, Samuel Zell — show these conflicts on a grand scale, DealBook wrote in a column in Sunday’s New York Times. Tribune, a publishing and broadcasting giant, did take steps to preserve objectivity, forming a special committee and hiring an outside adviser. But the situation still raises questions about whether Mr. Zell was given a privileged seat at the negotiating table.

abstract: Mirant, a power company with a market capitalization of more than $10 billion, said early Monday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore strategic options including a possible sale of the entire company. The strategic review, which Mirant said was intended to “enhance stockholder value,” comes less than a year after Mirant withdrew its hostile bid for a rival, NRG Energy, after the $8 billion offer sparked a shareholder revolt. A few months ago, the Texas utility TXU agreed to be acquired by a pair of private equity firms, leading some analysts to suggest that Mirant could be a possible takeover candidate as well.

abstract: In these days of flush private equity funds, the markets seem afraid to discount even unlikely-seeming rumors of a leveraged buyout. abstract: Carried interest, a major source of fees for private equity funds, has been the subject of controversy in recent weeks, as some lawmakers started talking up the notion of taxing it at a higher rate. Now comes more fodder for debate: Buyouts magazine reports that some midsize private equity firms are raising their carried interest (essentially their cut of the profits from a fund’s investments) from the industry standard of 20 percent to 25 percent. As described by Dan Primack of PE Week Wire, the higher fee is part of a tradeoff: In exchange for the extra 5 percent, a firm agrees to hold down the size of the fund it is raising.

abstract: Shares of Palm were down 2.6 percent to $17.16 in late-afternoon trading Monday, even as the major stock indexes hardly budged. Investors may simply have been nervous ahead of Palm’s analyst and investor day on Tuesday. Or they may have been reacting to statements by Palm chief executive Ed Colligan in an interview with Bloomberg News, in which he said that he is not concerned about calls for his company to be sold. Just a few weeks ago, reports on Unstrung.com, CNBC and elsewhere fueled takeover speculation about Palm, which makes the Treo smartphone, lifting its shares as high as $19.50 in intraday trading. No bid materialized, and the stock has fallen more than 11 percent.

abstract: The trade surplus widened 21 percent in March from the previous month, because of higher prices for copper, the country’s top export. The surplus was smaller than the $2.89 billion surplus in March 2006 but was in line with analysts’ forecasts. Chilean exports rose to $5.5 billion, from $4.57 billion the previous month, while imports climbed to $3.47 billion, from $2.9 billion, the bank said.

abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software’s chief financial officer became the latest casualty at the beleaguered video game publisher following a shareholder revolt spearheaded by several activist investors. The financial officer, Karl H. Winters, announced his resignation Monday, less than two weeks after the chief executive and several board members were ousted by shareholders.

abstract: For those wondering if private equity could sustain it’s run of record fund-raising, the answer is: yes, it apparently can. Fund-raising by private equity firms in the United States rose 67 percent in the first quarter, according to Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst. Sixty-eight funds have raised $44.3 billion in the first quarter of 2007, compared with the 46 funds that raised $26.6 billion in the first quarter of last year, the newsletter said. In 2006, private equity firms raised a total $246.3 billion in 359 funds.

abstract: Salesforce.com, best known for its hosted sales applications, is pushing into Web content management. The company on Tuesday expects to detail new products and the acquisition of start-up Koral, which created a Web content management service tied to Salesforce.com. Terms of the purchase of Koral, a nine-person firm based in San Mateo, Calif., which first launched its product last fall, were not disclosed.

abstract: Much ink has been spilled on the question of whether social networking site Facebook will sell out and, if so, for how much. Following Google‘s $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube last year, rumors percolated that Yahoo and Viacom were interested, and that Facebook’s founder and chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, was holding out for a $2 billion offer.

abstract: China Citic Bank plans to raise up to 30.14 billion Hong Kong dollars ($3.86 billion) in an initial public offering ahead of its Hong Kong listing on April 27, a news report said Tuesday. abstract: The takeover drums are once again pounding out the name Algoma Steel. Algoma shares jumped 2.36 Canadian dollars to close at 53.89 Canadian dollars ($46.96) Monday on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The activity was fueled by several factors, including a report in the industry newsletter Steel Business Briefing, word that Algoma’s management will brief potential bidders for the company this week, and the steady rise in steel prices.

abstract: Two former executives at Endocare, a medical products company based in Irvine, Calif., were indicted Monday for allegedly helping to inflate company revenue in a fraud that cost investors more than $200 million. A former chief executive, Paul W. Mikus, and a former chief financial officer, John V. Cracchiolo, were charged with wire fraud, securities fraud, filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and lying to Endocare’s accountants.

abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market posted its strongest first quarter performance for initial public offerings listings since the beginning of 2000. The total number of public offerings for the first quarter of 2007 came to 42, Nasdaq said. abstract: Despite fears that burdensome federal regulations are scaring companies away, markets in the United States are getting more foreign listings, TheStreet.com reported. During the first quarter, 19 percent of the 67 initial public offerings on the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq Stock Market and the American Stock Exchange were foreign-based, according to Dealogic. That’s up from 16 percent for all of last year.

abstract: Shares of BCE, which owns Bell Canada, were up as much as 7 percent Tuesday after it was reported that the company’s largest shareholder was contacting other investors about a possible takeover bid. DealBook has also learned that Ontario Teachers’ held talks with Providence Equity Partners, a United States-based private equity firm that specializes in media and telecommunications investments.

abstract: For a company whose raison d’etre is publishing financial data, Bloomberg LP is remarkably stingy with details about its own financial picture. But that has not stopped Fortune magazine from trying to guess how much the company, founded by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, is worth. Using lots of back-of-the-envelope estimates, bolstered by some hitherto unreleased financial information from the company itself, Fortune calculates that Bloomberg LP may be worth about $20 billion. That would give Mr. Bloomberg, who owns more than two-thirds of the company, a stake worth a cool $13 billion.
lead_paragraph: For a company whose raison d’etre is publishing financial data, Bloomberg LP is remarkably stingy with details about its own financial picture. Using lots of back-of-the-envelope estimates, bolstered by some hitherto unreleased financial information from the company itself, Fortune calculates that Bloomberg LP may be worth about $20 billion. That would give Mr. Bloomberg, who owns more than two-thirds of the company, a stake worth a cool $13 billion.

headline.main: Is Michael Bloomberg Worth $13 Billion?

abstract: The struggle for the Chicago Board of Trade is more than just another bidding war. To hear the Chicago Tribune tell it, it represents a larger power grab by big New York investment banks, who favor a late bid from the IntercontinentalExchange over the previous offer from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. It is, the Chicago newspaper suggested Tuesday, the Big Apple versus the City of Big Shoulders, with New York interests working hard to make sure their city tops Chicago in the market for exchange-traded derivatives.

abstract: Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail for contempt of court, was sentenced Tuesday to five additional years in prison for running what prosecutors say was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme. Judge John F. Keenan of the Southern District of New York also ordered Mr. Armstrong to pay restitution to the fraud victims, who are to receive $80 million — plus one dollar more — from Mr. Armstrong and others involved in the alleged scheme.

abstract: As NBC’s “Today” prepares for its “Where in the World Is Matt Lauer?” feature, Hyundai will sponsor a Web site following the host.

lead_paragraph: SINCE 1998, NBC has been sending a “Today” host to far-flung locales like Angkor Wat, Easter Island and Machu Picchu, all for a feature on the show called “Where in the World Is Matt Lauer?” This week, to help promote the next installment, Mr. Lauer is taking his most ambitious foray so far into cyberspace.

headline.main: Where on the Web Is Matt Lauer?

abstract: The American decision to complain to the World Trade Organization will “seriously undermine” relations on trade, the Chinese government said.

headline.print_headline: China Says It Regrets U.S. Action

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, April 9 — When Queen Elizabeth needs groceries, her staff usually sends out to Fortnum & Mason. Household goods at Buckingham Palace often come from the Selfridges department store. And the tea poured at royal tea parties is likely to have been blended by R. Twining & Company.

headline.main: Purveyor to the Queen Faces Test From Wal-Mart

abstract: Strauss Zelnick has taken on risky corporate restructurings before, but he says none have been as complex as at Take-Two Interactive Software, where he was named chairman two weeks ago.

lead_paragraph: The closest Strauss Zelnick usually gets to playing video games is watching over the shoulders of his two young sons. abstract: Romania’s low wages and recent membership in the European Union are fueling a wave of emigration that threatens to slow an economic boom in recent years.

lead_paragraph: BACAU, Romania — To get around the chronic labor shortages hampering this traditional textile center and in other industries across Romania, Sorin Nicolescu, who runs a clothing factory, came up with an original solution: import 800 workers from China.

abstract: The Einstein Noah Restaurant Group, a chain of bagel stores controlled by a hedge fund, Greenlight Capital, filed Tuesday to sell as much as $125 million in stock in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq. The company, whose stock now trades on the Pink Sheets, said it owns or franchises about 600 locations in the United States under the names Einstein Bros. Bagels, Noah’s New York Bagels and Manhattan Bagel. Morgan Stanley and Cowen are joint bookrunning managers for the offering.

abstract: A resolution that aimed to give Morgan Stanley shareholders a greater say in how top executives are paid failed to win a majority of votes cast at the firm’s annual meeting Tuesday. The defeat — only 37 percent voted in favor of the motion — represents a setback for activist investors who are seeking to gain a greater say in how executives are paid at dozens of companies.

abstract: The media magnate Conrad M. Black was urged by his company to use a corporate jet to travel to the Pacific island of Bora Bora on vacation because of safety concerns and did not represent an illegal siphoning off of claims, his lawyers suggested on Tuesday. A defense lawyer, Edward L. Greenspan, brushed aside the prosecution’s claim, saying the audit committee of the board of Mr. Black’s Hollinger International media empire urged executives to take the company’s Gulfstream 4 jet as a security measure “because of the nature of the business this company was in.”

abstract: Advisers to Barclays and ABN Amro could share about $100 million in fees for their work on what would be the biggest financial-services merger in history, based on comparable fees from previous deals, Bloomberg News reported. While hardly a small sum, the amount would be one-third less than what advisers charged last year for AT&T’s purchase of BellSouth, underscoring how financial-services deals tend to bring relatively lower fees than transactions in other industries.

abstract: Magna International, the Canadian auto parts supplier has teamed up with a Canadian private equity firm, Onex, to make a run at DaimlerChrysler‘s Chrysler Group, according to The Globe and Mail. The idea behind the bid for Chrysler is that Magna would bring its expertise to operating auto factories, while Onex would use its financial finesse to run Chrysler’s credit arm, the report said.

abstract: Vivendi‘s former vice chairman Edgar Bronfman Jr. sued the company Tuesday, alleging it improperly cut his pension payments by 65 percent. In a lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Bronfman, now chief executive of the Warner Music Group, contends that Vivendi, the French entertainment group, reduced his pension last year after claiming it had erroneously been crediting him for 15 years of service beyond the 20 years of actual service Bronfman had already accrued.

abstract: A real estate company, Unibail Holding, said it had offered $15 billion in stock for a Dutch rival, Rodamco Europe, and that the board and a key shareholder of Rodamco had endorsed the deal. The companies estimated their combined real estate portfolios, focused primarily on European shopping malls, would have been worth 21.7 billion euros ($29 billion) in 2006 with rental income of 974 million euros.

abstract: Goldman Sachs manages $147 billion in alternative assets, making the securities firm a behemoth in the hedge-fund business. So why, asks Thorold Barker of The Financial Times, doesn’t Goldman enjoy the same heady market valuation as Fortress Investment Group, which recently went public? Part of the problem, he suggests, is the “black box” factor: Goldman simply doesn’t tell investors and analysts much about its hedge fund operations. If the firm wants more credit for its hedge fund prowess, it might want to consider pulling back the veil a bit.

Part of the problem, he suggests, is the “black box” factor: Goldman simply doesn’t tell investors and analysts much about its hedge fund operations. If the firm wants more credit for its hedge fund prowess, it might want to consider pulling back the veil a bit.

headline.main: Should Goldman Crack Open the Black Box?

abstract: CVC, the private equity firm attempting to mount a bid for J Sainsbury, has enlisted the backing of the private equity division of Goldman Sachs in a last-ditch attempt to rescue its fast-collapsing proposed deal for the British supermarket chain, according to The Telegraph.

abstract: Cerberus Capital Management, the Fortress Investment Group and D.E. Shaw are among the hedge funds who have been buying shares in bankrupt companies in an attempt to influence the restructuring or force acquisitions, according to Financial News. Shareholders typically have little say in bankruptcy proceedings, but funds with equity stakes have been taking active roles in cases involving Calpine, Northwest Airlines and Delphi, among others.

abstract: Barclays Bank‘s 80 billion pound ($158 billion) merger with ABN Amro took another step forward as ABN rushed to settle legal action over money transfers and the government regulator in The Netherlands said that, in principle, it did not object to takeovers by foreign banks. The Telegraph reported that ABN is attempting to reach an agreement with the United States Department of Justice over certain deficiencies in its anti-money-laundering systems.

abstract: Vision Investment Management, a manager of an Aisan fund that invests in various hedge funds, has raised about $55 million for a new vehicle that will seed and incubate hedge fund start-ups, Reuters reported. The firm’s Vision Angel Fund is likely to invest with its first two managers within 30 to 45 days, Julius Wang, a managing director with the Hong Kong-based firm, told the wire service. He said that the investment target size will be between $100 million to $150 million.

abstract: Democratic presidential hopeful Barack Obama apparently spent Monday rubbing shoulders with some of New York’s financiers at a round of fund-raising events in Manhattan. Less than a week after the Obama team announced that he had all but matched Hillary Clinton’s first-quarter fund-raising totals of $26 million, Mr. Obama was back at it, answering questions at the home of a retired investment banker, Steven Gluckstern, an event that The New York Observer says was co-hosted by a money manager, Whitney Tilson, and an investment banker, Bob Ennis.

abstract: Financial services firms helped office rents in Manhattan reach record highs in the first three months of 2007, the real estate brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield said Tuesday. Financial services accounted for 35.7 percent of leasing during the quarter, as rents in Midtown reached a record average $70.77 a square foot, with some surpassing $150 a square foot, Cushman & Wakefield said.

abstract: Speculation over the fate of the three Trump Entertainment casinos in Atlantic City has heightened since mid-March, when the company disclosed that it had hired Merrill Lynch to “explore all our options,” as Donald Trump, who owns 30 percent of the holding company, put it. That includes the possibility that the company might sell all three properties – or perhaps dispose of a single hotel to raise the capital to improve the other two.

abstract: The boom in mergers and acquisitions that made retailers and apparel makers prized targets and resulted in ownership changes for marquee names such as Neiman Marcus, May Department Stores and Toys ‘R’ Us, is finally cooling, The New York Post said Wednesday. In year-to-date figures, retail and apparel companies accounted for just 2.9 percent of overall mergers and acquisitions activity compared with a recent high of 8 percent for the same period in 2005, the paper said, citing data from Thomson Financial.

abstract: The private-equity firms fighting to save their $27 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications are weighing their options ahead of a crucial vote on the deal next week, the New York Post reported citing unnamed sources. Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital — which struck a deal last year to buy Clear Channel for $37.60 a share — held serious discussions over the past week on whether to increase their offer for the radio giant in order to appease a group of cantankerous shareholders demanding a sweeter deal.

abstract: Manor Care, a nursing-home operator, said Wednesday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore a “full range of opportunities” to add shareholder value. The company did not give any specifics about the alternatives under review but said in a news release that it was “well-positioned to consider taking advantage of currently attractive conditions in the financial markets.” Manor Care’s stock surged after the announcement, rising 11 percent in early trading Wednesday to $61.65, a 52-week high. At that price, the company has a market capitalization of about $4.5 billion.

abstract: Shares of Citigroup declined more than 1 percent Wednesday after the company gave details about its long-awaited plan to cut costs. Citi’s stock — which has made only modest gains in the past three years, frustrating many investors — had been rising in recent days in anticipation of the announcement, which followed a companywide review led by Citi’s chief operating officer, Robert Druskin. Analysts said the plan, which includes 17,000 job cuts and 9,500 job reassignments or relocations, was generally in line with what Wall Street had expected.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Citigroup declined more than 1 percent Wednesday after the company gave details about its long-awaited plan to cut costs. Citi’s stock — which has made only modest gains in the past three years, frustrating many investors — had been rising in recent days in anticipation of the announcement, which followed a companywide review led by Citi’s chief operating officer, Robert Druskin. Analysts said the plan, which includes 17,000 job cuts and 9,500 job reassignments or relocations, was generally in line with what Wall Street had expected.

headline.main: Update: Citi Shares Fall After Revamp Is Announced

abstract: We hate to pile on a company when it’s down, but we couldn’t resist running some numbers on Vonage Holdings, the upstart Internet-based phone company whose initial public offering last year has gone from bad to worse to apocalyptically awful. With the latest downtick in Vonage’s stock, coming after a federal judge ordered it to stop using technology licensed by Verizon, the I.P.O. is by far the worst of 2006, according to Thomson Financial. At $3, the stock has lost more than 82 percent of its value since last May, when it was sold to the public at $17 apiece. The shares are now below the average price paid by Vonage’s pre-I.P.O. investors, a prestigious group of venture and private equity investors including New Enterprise Associates, Meritech Capital Partners, 3i, and Bain Capital.

abstract: It appears someone may have pulled a fast one on Bloomberg News — and, by extension, DealBook. abstract: Initial public offerings “are back – and tech I.P.O.’s are really back,” writes Brian Caulfield of Forbes.com. But “the most heavily hyped segment of the tech boom — the glitzy ‘Web 2.0’ companies — has produced a grand total of zero stock offerings. What gives?” There are various meanings of Web 2.0, and this article doesn’t quite offer up a definition, but it makes reference to the kind of buzzy, Web-based companies backed by venture investors such as Benchmark Capital, Draper Fisher Jurvetson and Sequoia Capital and contrasts them with the networking- and telecom-related tech firms that have held I.P.O.’s this year.

abstract: Wednesday brought two developments related to CNBC correspondent Maria Bartiromo: One brought some closure, the other was a closing. The Financial Times reported that Todd S. Thomson, the Citigroup executive whose dismissal raised questions about his ties to Ms. Bartiromo, has reached a deal with Citi over his severance package. What’s next for Mr. Thomson, who was once considered a contender to lead Citi? Bloomberg News said he has set up a real estate development firm called Headwaters Capital as he considers his options. In other real-estate news — yes, we are reaching for a segue here — The New York Observer reports that Ms. Bartiromo and her husband, Jonathan Steinberg, have closed their purchase of a five-level, $6.5 million townhouse on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.

abstract: The latest issue of Trader Monthly, which features a list of the 100 top-earning hedge fund managers, writes that Daniel Loeb’s “venomous tongue has fallen silent of late and his legendarily incendiary memos have disappeared.” We beg to differ. Proof to the contrary came Wednesday in a blistering letter to the board of PDL Biopharma, a drug development company in which Mr. Loeb’s hedge fund firm, Third Point, owns a 9.7 percent stake. In the letter, which was distributed in a press release, Mr. Loeb urges PDL to remove its chief executive, Mark McDade, whom he describes as being “fixated on when his boat slip in the marina adjacent to the new corporate headquarters will be ready” rather than on his company’s underperforming stock.

abstract: A panel of the European Parliament is set to recommend that fees Europeans pay for making and receiving mobile phone calls outside their home markets be lowered by more than originally expected, dealing a setback to the telecommunications industry. Members of the Industry, Research and Energy Committee are expected to approve a proposal today to reduce so-called roaming charges to a maximum 0.40 euro for outgoing calls, and 0.15 euro for incoming calls, plus the value-added tax. Leaders of all major political parties on the 52-member panel except the Greens have endorsed the plan, according to a copy of their agreement obtained by The International Herald Tribune. If it receives the committee’s support, the proposal will go before the full Parliament on May 9.

abstract: Magna, the Canadian auto parts manufacturer, said that a former president, Belinda Stronach, left, the daughter of the company’s founder and controlling shareholder, Frank Stronach, would be returning to the company to be the executive vice chairwoman. The company said that Ms. Stronach would not seek re-election to the Canadian Parliament, where she has served since 2004. Magna has been discussed by auto analysts as a possible bidder for the Chrysler division of the DaimlerChrysler Corporation. “My father is looking to the future, the company is facing important strategic decisions, and the Canadian and global auto sector and economy are in a period of great challenge,” Ms. Stronach said in a statement.

lead_paragraph: Fans of sports like skiing, snowboarding and skateboarding can now measure their time off the ground with DropZone’s HangTimer, a multifunction sports watch with a little something extra. When tucked in a pocket or clipped to a belt loop, the HangTimer uses its “tri-axis accelerometer” to sense when the wearer has left terra firma and then measures each hundredth of a second aloft  otherwise known as hang time.

abstract: The buyout firm CVC Capital Partners scrapped a £10 billion ($19.7 billion) bid for J Sainsbury, the British grocery chain, after CVC was abandoned by its bidding partners and Sainsbury’s founding family held out for more money. The family, which owns about 18 percent of the retailer, wanted more than the 582 pence ($11.46) that CVC bid for each share. “It became clear that the consortium would be unable to make a proposal” that would succeed, CVC said in a statement. The Blackstone Group, the Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company all left the bidding consortium in the last week. Selling to the private equity group would have risked damaging the company’s “strong balance sheet and a largely freehold property base,” said John Sainsbury, former chief executive of the company. “Eroding these attributes would make the company more vulnerable to competitive pressures.”.

abstract: Nestlé, the world’s largest food company, agreed to buy the baby food giant Gerber for $5.5 billion in cash to extend its push into the health and wellness category. Gerber, famous for its Gerber Baby ads, is currently owned by Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceuticals company, which has been selling noncore businesses in recent years to focus on health care. Separately, Novartis said Thursday it had named Joseph Jimenez, previously of the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, to be chief executive of its consumer health division.
lead_paragraph: Nestlé, the world’s largest food company, agreed to buy the baby food giant Gerber for $5.5 billion in cash to extend its push into the health and wellness category. abstract: It was just yesterday that DealBook was observing how Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, has the dubious honor of being the worst initial public offering, by far, of 2006. Then came word Thursday morning that Vonage’s chief executive, Michael Snyder, has abruptly stepped down and resigned from Vonages’ its board of directors. Thursday’s news release gave no reason for Mr. Snyder’s departure, but the company is clearly in crisis mode. Its stock has lost more than 80 percent of its value since it went public in May, and Vonage is at risk of losing access to an important piece of technology that is the subject of a patent dispute with Verizon.

Thursday’s news release gave no reason for Mr. Snyder’s departure, but the company is clearly in crisis mode. headline.main: Vonage’s Chief Executive Resigns

abstract: MedImmune, citing recent approaches from “major pharmaceutical companies” and dissatisfaction within its shareholder ranks, said Thursday it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it look for potential buyers. MedImmune, a biotechnology company whose products include the flu vaccine FluMist, had a market capitalization of about $9 billion based on Wednesday’s closing share price; the shares surged more than 8 percent in premarket trading Thursday. The company said there was no guarantee it would be sold and added that it would not give any public updates on the process until it was complete.
lead_paragraph: MedImmune, citing recent approaches from “major pharmaceutical companies” and dissatisfaction within its shareholder ranks, said Thursday it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it look for potential buyers. MedImmune, a biotechnology company whose products include the flu vaccine FluMist, had a market capitalization of about $9 billion based on Wednesday’s closing share price; the shares surged more than 8 percent in premarket trading Thursday. The company said there was no guarantee it would be sold and added that it would not give any public updates on the process until it was complete.

headline.main: MedImmune Puts Itself Up for Sale

abstract: The Russians may be planning another multibillion-dollar deal in North America. Ipsco, a Canadian steelmaker with executive offices in the United States, said Thursday that it is in discussions that could lead to a sale of the company. Ipsco did not identify the potential buyer, but the statement followed a report in a Russian newspaper that Russian steel company Evraz Group was in takeover talks with Ipsco. Ipsco’s shares jumped nearly 7 percent on Thursday, giving it a market capitalization of about $6.6 billion.

abstract: Fortress Investment Group is not a stock for the faint of heart. Its shares surged 68 percent when they hit the market in February in what was the first public stock offering from a United States hedge fund and private equity firm. Since the offering, the shares have swung as high as $37 and as low as $23.34. The company generates eye-popping returns through its various funds, but many parts of its profit-making machine are proprietary secrets. So it was remarkable to learn, thanks to some filing-watchers at Financial News, that Fidelity Investments, the world’s largest mutual fund company, has bought more than a quarter of the shares that Fortress sold in the I.P.O., giving it a 10 percent stake in the company.
lead_paragraph: Fortress Investment Group is not a stock for the faint of heart. Since the offering, the shares have swung as high as $37 and as low as $23.34. The company generates eye-popping returns through its various funds, but many parts of its profit-making machine are proprietary secrets. So it was remarkable to learn, thanks to some filing-watchers at Financial News, that Fidelity Investments, the world’s largest mutual fund company, has bought more than a quarter of the shares that Fortress sold in the I.P.O., giving it a 10 percent stake in the company.

headline.main: Fidelity Makes a Big Bet on Fortress

abstract: Three days after it insisted it was not up for sale, Dow Chemical has fired two executives it claims held unauthorized talks to sell the company. Mr. Reinhard was Dow’s chief financial officer until late 2005.

abstract: It seems that John F. Welch Jr.’s dream of becoming a newspaper baron will have to wait. Speaking before an audience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the former chairman of General Electric said Thursday that The New York Times Company has made it clear that the Boston Globe is not for sale. Last year, Mr. Welch expressed an interest in buying The Globe, and he joined with Jack Connors, co-founder of Boston advertising agency Hill Holliday, to explore making an offer. But the Times Company has repeatedly said that The Globe is not on the block, and Mr. Welch appears to have gotten the message.

lead_paragraph: Money cannot buy happiness, but it can help with optimism.A poll from The Los Angeles Times and Bloomberg reports that most Americans think a recession is at least somewhat likely over the next year. Those making less than $40,000 a year are far more likely to think that will happen. So are blacks, and women are much more pessimistic than men.

abstract: One of the two men fired by Dow Chemical on Thursday has rejected allegations that he held unauthorized talks with potential buyers of the company. “The behavior of the company is very unusual, and the accusations have absolutely no substance and are highly damaging to my reputation after 30 years of employment,” Romeo Kreinberg told The Associated Press. Mr. Kreinberg, who had been an executive vice president at Dow, was dismissed Thursday along with Pedro Reinhard, a member of Dow’s board, for holding what the company said were “highly inappropriate” talks with third parties about a possible sale of Dow Chemical.

Ramos, dismissed breach of fiduciary duty and negligent misrepresentation claims against the exchange itself in connection with its 2005 merger with Archipelago Holdings and its transformation from a not-for-profit to a public company.

headline.main: Suit Over N.Y.S.E. Merger to Proceed, Judge Rules

abstract: Morgan Stanley is buying 13 hotels from Japanese carrier All Nippon Airways for 281 billion yen ($2.4 billion), the airline said Friday, in a transaction that would roughly double the investment bank’s portfolio of hotels in Japan. The deal, to be completed June 1, includes high-end hotels in Tokyo, the resort island of Okinawa as well as northern and southern Japan, ANA said in a statement.

abstract: The irony of Thursday’s spectacle at Dow Chemical, which fired two senior executives for allegedly engaging in rogue negotiations to sell the company, is that it may have whetted investors’ and suitors’ appetite for a Dow takeover. “I find it interesting how private equity had penetrated the highest levels of the company,” HSBC Securities analyst Hassan Ahmed told Bloomberg News. The announcement “is telling us that there are parties interested in making that bid.” Shares of Dow rose 2 percent Thursday as some suggested that, while these talks appear to have been bungled, Dow could still make an attractive takeover target for Middle East investors or private equity firms. Breakingviews said this may be an example of “the wrong people doing the right thing.”

The announcement “is telling us that there are parties interested in making that bid.” Shares of Dow rose 2 percent Thursday as some suggested that, while these talks appear to have been bungled, Dow could still make an attractive takeover target for Middle East investors or private equity firms. abstract: Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion. A buyout, if completed, would be an impressive show of muscle-flexing by private equity firms, which have grown emboldened over the last two years by acquiring ever larger targets. Shares of Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, jumped more than 11 percent Friday in premarket trading.

abstract: Midwest Air‘s board has again rebuff AirTran‘s hostile offer for the airline. In a statement on Friday, the board said it recommends that the company’s shareholders reject the discount airline’s revised $15 a share tender offer, saying the new bid remains too low. Nearly two weeks ago, after AirTran raised its offer a third time, Midwest’s board told shareholders that it would evaluate the new proposal.

abstract: Shares of Sallie Mae were up as much as 11 percent in early trading Friday as investors reacted to a report that the United States’ largest lender to college students was in talks about a possible buyout. The New York Times said the negotiations for Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, were at a late stage and named Blackstone Group as one of the potential bidders. Sallie Mae’s stock surged $4.44 to $45.19 early Friday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $18.6 billion. Despite the rise, however, the shares are still well below their 52-week high of $55.21, which they reached in May 2006.

abstract: As some people fret about conspicuous consumption, high levels of consumer debt and the world’s growing income gap, Merrill Lynch has come up with a way for investors to profit from these trends. The investment bank has introduced a Luxury and Lifestyle Index, which it described in a press release as the first “tradable certificate” that tracks shares of luxury goods companies, such as BMW, Bulgari, and Bang & Olufsen. Merrill’s new index also includes some less-exclusive names such as Avon and The Gap.

abstract: Citigroup agreed to buy hedge fund Old Lane Partners as part of a deal that puts a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group. Citigroup, the global banking giant, has spent months courting the executive, Vikram Pandit, who left Morgan Stanley in 2005 after he was blocked for a chance at running the investment bank. Financial terms were not disclosed, but The New York Times reported Friday that the transaction was expected to cost $600 million to $800 million.

abstract: Cott, the Canadian maker of private-label soft-drink brands for retailers such as Wal-Mart, said Friday that it is in talks with potential partners and is “exploring the potential benefits of participating in possible industry consolidation.” Cott didn’t name any of the potential partners, but the press release included a reference to Cadbury Schweppes, which last month announced plans to split its candy division from its drinks division. The Wall Street Journal reported Friday that Cott is negotiating with private equity firms about combining its operations with Cadbury’s beverage arm. The report sent Cott’s shares up nearly 30 percent.

Not only does April 15 fall on a Sunday, pushing the deadline out one day, but also (who knew?) the District of Columbia is celebrating Emancipation Day on Monday (in honor of when Abraham Lincoln officially ended slavery there). Through a quirk of the law, that means the entire country does not have to file taxes until Tuesday.

Yet dark clouds can give way to clear skies provided you have a generous expense account. A pickup from the airport in a luxury automobile? Sure. Hotel check-in at the bar instead of the lobby? abstract: Not having an office is a problem faced by most business travelers who might have a two-hour gap between meetings.
snippet: Not having an office is a problem faced by most business travelers who might have a two-hour gap between meetings.
lead_paragraph: AS a consultant to companies that want to expand their international reach, Albert Jones often finds himself far from his base in Chicago. But when he goes to meetings in places like Britain, Bahrain or Indonesia, he does not rely on a hotel conference center, a cramped hotel room or even a cafe to be his makeshift office. Instead, before each trip, he arranges to work in spaces run by the Regus Group, which has a network of 950 locations, consisting of meeting rooms and individual offices, which can be secured for an hour, a day or longer in cities as small as Frisco, Tex., and as far-flung as Abu Dhabi.

headline.main: By the Hour or the Day, an Office of One’s Own
headline.print_headline: By the Hour or the Day, An Office of One’s Own

abstract: A number of  technology advances will be announced, including an initiative that could give rise to a new class of wireless hand-held computers.

abstract: A consortium of three banks that is threatening to gate-crash merger talks between Barclays and ABN Amro are considering an offer that would reportedly lead to the break-up of the Dutch bank’s assets. The three bidders, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander Central Hispano and Fortis, which on Friday said that they have asked ABN Amro to enagage in exploratory talks, are proposing to carve up ABN Amro and give its shareholders a package of shares in each of their institutions, The Guardian reported.

abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, continued his campaign to gain a seat on Motorola‘s board, this time making his pitch directly to the cellphone maker’s shareholders. In a letter to shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission Friday, Mr. Icahn said that the company’ financial woes “reflect not only operational failures, but are also symptoms of a passive and reactive board.”

abstract: Charles B. Wang, the founder and former chairman of Computer Associates, oversaw a decade-long accounting fraud at the software company, according to a report released Friday by the company’s directors. Mr. Wang, who owns the New York Islanders and is among the most politically influential people on Long Island, masterminded accounting gimmicks that inflated his company’s sales and profits for years, the report says. In 25 years running Computer Associates, Mr. Wang built a fortune of about $1 billion, including a bonus in 1998 of $670 million.

abstract: Despite high office rents, New York City is emerging as the new home of the mega-rich hedge fund trader – stealing a bit of the thunder from Greenwich, Conn., The New York Post reports. abstract: Several large private equity firms submitted first-round bids for Home Depot‘s HD Supply unit, but Home Depot may not be all that interested in selling the unit, according to The Deal.com. When the company said in February that it was considering strategic alternatives, HD Supply was seen as a distraction to Home Depot’s core business. But with the housing market slowing dramatically in recent months, analysts now say the unit, which is less reliant on the residential housing market, could help the retailer weather the housing storm.

abstract: Quest Diagnostics, the biggest U.S. provider of medical tests, will buy AmeriPath in a deal worth about $2 billion to increase the ability to screen for cancer. The transaction includes the assumption of about $770 million in debt, the companies said Monday in a statement. AmeriPath, based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., is owned by Welsh, Carson, Anderson and Stowe, a venture capital firm. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter.

abstract: A large group of floor traders at the New York Board of Trade are furious with their new owners at the IntercontinentalExchange and are about to launch a publicity campaign meant to derail the exchange’s offer for the Chicago Board of Trade, The New York Post reported Monday. lead_paragraph: PUBLIC SERVICE: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL The Wall Street Journal was honored for what the Pulitzer Prize Board called “its creative and comprehensive probe into backdated stock options for business executives,” as a result of which more than 70 executives, including some chief executives, have been fired or have quit and 10 have been criminally charged. “It was like an incredibly well-hidden secret in corporate America,” said Mark Maremont, who reported and wrote the articles along with Charles Forelle, James Bandler and Steve Stecklow.

abstract: As private equity firms consider an ever-widening array of industries for megabuyouts, an analyst at Bear Stearns suggests they might want to go shopping in a somewhat more conventional place: the retail sector. Christopher Horvers ticked off a list of reasons for buyout funds to look at “hardline” retailers, a category that includes appliance, furniture and electronics chains, and he names a few promising candidates such as Bed Bath & Beyond and Circuit City. The analyst said that many of these companies have qualities that would endear them to private equity buyers, including mature businesses, predictable cash flows, relatively little “merchandising risk” (as compared to apparel retailers, who face fickle fashion trends) and strong balance sheets.

headline.main: Seeing Buyout Bargains in the Retail Business

abstract: J. Pedro Reinhard has rejected Dow Chemical‘s claim that he took part in unauthorized talks to sell the company, an alleged offense that prompted Dow last week to dismiss him as a senior adviser and to fire Romeo Kreinberg, an executive vice president. In a statement distributed Monday, Mr. Reinhard said “I categorically deny that I have been part of any secret effort to take over or acquire Dow Chemical” (an assertion that a stickler might say does not rule out the possibility that he was involved in non-secret efforts to sell the company).

abstract: MORE TRANS-ATLANTIC COMPETITION Zoom Airlines, based in Ottawa, plans to begin service between Kennedy International Airport and London Gatwick Airport on June 21, with round-trip coach fares starting at about $510, including taxes and fees. Zoom says it will offer both economy and premium- economy cabins with meals. EOS ADDS SERVICE Eos Airlines, the discount all- business-class carrier, expanded its schedule to add a third flight between Kennedy International Airport and Stansted Airport in London. The additional flight will leave from Kennedy on Sundays, Mondays and Fridays and from Gatwick on Sundays, Mondays and Fridays. AMERICAN AIRLINES PROTEST Flight attendants for American Airlines will be picketing at domestic airports today to protest $180 million in bonuses the carrier is preparing to pay to about 1,000 top managers, according to the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which represents nearly 20,000 flight attendants at American. In 2003, the flight attendants at American agreed to significant cuts in pay as the airline and others in the industry faced serious financial strain.

abstract: Carlyle Group, the giant Washington-based private equity fund, has reportedly suffered a new setback in China. The weekly business magazine Caijing reported that Chinese government regulators have rejected Carlyle’s bid to take a 7.99 percent stake in Chongqing Commercial Bank, ostensibly because of a banking rule that prevents foreign investors with total assets of less than $10 billion from becoming a major shareholder in Chinese commercial banks. The rule, which is not consistently applied in China, would virtually disqualify all regional private-equity funds active in the Asia-Pacific area, Forbes.com reported.

The rule, which is not consistently applied in China, would virtually disqualify all regional private-equity funds active in the Asia-Pacific area, Forbes.com reported.

headline.main: More China Trouble for Carlyle?

abstract: Delta Air Lines said Monday that unofficial voting results show its reorganization plan has received enough creditor support to be approved. The Atlanta-based carrier, which successfully fended off a hostile takeover bid from US Airways while in Chapter 11 protection, will go to court April 25 to ask a judge to confirm the plan, paving the way for it to emerge from bankruptcy on April 30. The Atlanta-based airline said in a statement that the results show that more than 95 percent of ballots cast were in favor of the plan.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines said Monday that unofficial voting results show its reorganization plan has received enough creditor support to be approved. The Atlanta-based carrier, which successfully fended off a hostile takeover bid from US Airways while in Chapter 11 protection, will go to court April 25 to ask a judge to confirm the plan, paving the way for it to emerge from bankruptcy on April 30. The Atlanta-based airline said in a statement that the results show that more than 95 percent of ballots cast were in favor of the plan.

headline.main: Delta Says Creditors Approved Reorganization Plan

abstract: Semiconductor maker Atmel‘s largest individual shareholder and former chief executive, George Perlegos, said Monday he proposed the company bring in a new board, hire a new C.E.O. and buy back up to $1 billion in shares. abstract: As more venture capitalists and entrepreneurs are choosing mergers and acquisitions rather than initial public offerings as their exit of choice, the trend has some in Silicon Valley worried, says The San Jose Mercury News. According to industry tracker VentureOne, 40 venture-backed Silicon Valley start-ups were acquired in the first quarter of this year, compared with 53 in all of 1997. Meanwhile,the region was home to 417 companies in 2000, compared with the 280 I.P.Os last year.

abstract: AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion. In a terse statement, AT&T did not give any reason for the decision to pull back its offer to buy a third of the controlling company, Olimpia. But The New York Times reports that AT&T became disenchanted with the idea following intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.

abstract: SoundBite Communications, a 7-year-old company that provides automated voicemail-message delivery, seeks to raise as much as $69 million in an initial public offering. SoundBite’s investors include North Bridge Venture Partners and Mosaic Venture Partners, and Cowen and Company and Thomas Weisel Partners are among the offering’s underwriters. According to SoundBite’s preliminary prospectus, it plans to use proceeds from the stock sale to repay $3.5 million in debt as well as for general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions.

abstract: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the largest U.S. public pension fund, said it will vote against the $19 billion purchase of Clear Channel Communications, becoming the third big shareholder to oppose the takeover. The fund owns 3.34 million shares of Clear Channel, or less than 1 percent of the largest U.S. radio broadcaster.
