abstract: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said Tuesday it was in discussions with a consortium of Canadian pension funds about a deal to take the company private. The consortium, led by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, the Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, and Canada’s Public Sector Pension Investment Board, also includes New York-based buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts as a minority partner, BCE said. Last week, The New York Times reported that the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, BCE’s largest shareholder, was in early talks with other investors about mounting a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE in what would be the largest buyout in history. BCE said at the time it was “not in any current talks with any other parties.”

abstract: Mark DeCambre admits up front that Goldman Sachs “isn’t considering a breakup right now.” But that hasn’t stopped Mr. DeCambre, who writes for TheStreet.com, from joining the others who have recently speculated about what such a hypothetical and unlikely breakup might mean for the hugely profitable securities giant. The main reason for all the what-iffing seems to be a fascination with Goldman’s rather opaque collection of businesses and a desire to compare Goldman with financial companies such as Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm with some Goldman-like features but a much higher valuation on Wall Street.

abstract: Hellman & Friedman is having a busy week. Just a few days ago, the San Francisco private equity firm agreed to sell portfolio company DoubleClick to Google for $3.1 billion, well above the $1.1 billion that Hellman and JMI Equity paid for the advertising firm just two years ago. On Tuesday, Hellman & Friedman announced that it raised $8.4 billion for its latest private equity fund, giving it plenty of ammunition for more deals. The new fund, which is the firm’s sixth, represents more than half of the $16 billion that Hellman & Friedman has raised since 1987.

abstract: Many backlashes bring a counter-backlash, and that may be what is going on with corporate crime. It has become trendy in certain circles to say that the government is cracking down too hard on company executives. James Surowiecki of the New Yorker has noticed this trend as relates to Conrad Black, the former chief of Hollinger International who is now being tried on fraud charges. Mr. Black — whose own defense lawyer has described him as egotistical and arrogant — is “not an obviously sympathetic figure,” as Mr. Surowiecki understates it. But even he is being defended by “journalists, legal commentators, and myriad bloggers,” Mr. Surowiecki writes.

abstract: Have a beef about Citigroup‘s stock price? Or did you find a strange charge on your bank account? Either way, you can take your idea straight to the top. Charles O. abstract: Texas power company TXU said on Wednesday it would proceed with its planned buyout by private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group after failing to attract a superior offer. TXU, which agreed in February to be bought for $45 billion by the private equity firms and other investors, said that during a 50-day “go-shop” period, in which it had the right to solicit other bids, it received no offer that could reasonably be expected to result in a superior proposal.

abstract: The Canadian National Railway lifted a lockout against striking workers in five cities after a special labor law, passed Tuesday by the House of Commons through a special accelerated process, was approved by the Senate and swiftly signed into law by Governor-General Michaëlle Jean, the formal head of state. An arbitrator will now impose a settlement. The United Transportation Union began rotating strikes against Canadian National last week after its workers overwhelmingly rejected a tentative contract. That proposed contract had ended a 15-day general strike in February that had caused industrial disruption in Canada and shipping delays to the United States. The dispute focuses on work rules, particularly those concerning older employees.

abstract: Telefónica, the Spanish phone operator, has agreed to sell its Airwave O2 unit, Britain’s police and emergency services radio network, to Macquarie Bank of Australia for £1.9 billion ($3.8 billion). The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group and Macquarie European Infrastructure Fund II, both managed by the bank, which is based in Sydney, will each own 50 percent of Airwave, they said in a statement. Marquarie is the world’s largest manager of infrastructure. Telefónica, based in Madrid, which has more debt than any other major European phone operator, is selling Airwave after shedding its phone directory business last year.

abstract: The president of the United Auto Workers said Wednesday he hopes to persuade DaimlerChrysler not to sell the Chrysler Group, even as a German magazine reported that Daimler could make a decision on a buyer in the next four weeks. Ron Gettelfinger, the union head who was speaking to reporters at Chrysler’s headquarters, said the union believed that it was still an option for Daimler to keep Chrysler, which reported an operating loss of $1.5 billion last year. “There is a lot of value in keeping it there right now because of the synergy, even though you don’t hear a lot about that,” he said. “It has worked well.”
lead_paragraph: The president of the United Auto Workers said Wednesday he hopes to persuade DaimlerChrysler not to sell the Chrysler Group, even as a German magazine reported that Daimler could make a decision on a buyer in the next four weeks. headline.main: Union Wants Daimler to Keep Chrysler

abstract: Some hedge funds apparently are making it hard for a private equity consortium to seal its $11.1 billion deal for the Australian airline Qantas. With just more than two weeks to go until their tender offer expires, the bidders, who include the Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group, are having trouble winning over shareholders, with the number of shares committed to the deal actually dropping since last week, according to Finance Asia.

abstract: TD Banknorth shareholders have approved a plan by Toronto-Dominion Bank, which already owns nearly 60 percent of the Bank, to acquire the rest of the shares for $3.6 billion. TD Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Maine, will then become a subsidiary of Toronto-dominion Bank, which is based in Toronto.

abstract: The recent outage that left five million BlackBerry users without their cherished wireless e-mail triggered some major withdrawal symptoms. People across the country frantically switched the devices on and off and made desperate calls to their help desks in an attempt to figure out what was wrong. “I quit smoking 28 years ago,” an executive at an insurance company told The New York Times, “and that was easier than being without my BlackBerry.”

abstract: A fight is brewing over a bill that would allow shareholders to have the right to a nonbinding vote on the pay packages of senior executives of public companies. The measure, which the House began debating Wednesday, would also give shareholders the right to vote on any “golden parachute” compensation plans that are awarded to executives while they are negotiating the purchase or sale of a company.

abstract: Merrill Lynch said Thursday that first-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to $2.16 billion, lifted by record investment-banking fees and trading revenue. Merrill’s chief executive, Stan O’Neal, called it a “terrific quarter” despite a sometimes volatile environment. Including Merrill’s latest figures, Bloomberg News reported that first-quarter profit at the five biggest securities firms in the nation totaled $9.7 billion, an all-time high. Separately, Bank of America said Thursday that first-quarter profit increased 5 percent to $5.26 billion, helped by growth in fee income.

abstract: The beleaguered recorded-music business has to do something to pull itself out of its current predicament, which stems partly from outside forces it cannot control (the Internet) but also from its own clumsy or outdated strategies. According to Fortune magazine’s Tim Arango, Warner Music Group‘s rumored deal to buy Front Line Management — the nation’s largest artist-management firm, with a roster of big-name clients including Christina Aguilera and Aerosmith — may offer “a new economic model for the major record companies.” He compares this model to venture capital investing, but with the record labels nurturing new talent instead of new technologies.

abstract: The Times of London takes a look at what it calls the “vicious feud” between London brokerage firm Tullett Prebon and Cantor Fitzgerald, the New York-based firm that rejected Tullett’s bid for eSpeed, its electronic bond-trading subsidiary. The account describes a “deep and vituperative” divide between the companies’ chief executives and even offers a timeline and a list of players in the trans-Atlantic contretemps. But somehow the article fails to mention one of the most colorful figures in the affair: The hedge fund manager Robert Chapman of Chapman Capital, who has been pushing for a sale of eSpeed.

abstract: Among Web 2.0 startups, few are more closely watched than Facebook, a social-networking Web site that was originally restricted to college students but has since opened the gates to many others as well. Much of the fascination comes from the decision by Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s young founder, not to accept offers to acquire Facebook, including a bid from Yahoo that The New York Times said was worth $900 million. (Others have rounded it up to an even $1 billion.) In a long profile of the oft-profiled Mr. Zuckerberg, Fast Company’s Ellen McGirt spends some time pondering how Facebook’s founders and its investors — who include PayPal founder Peter Thiel — might eventually cash out their stakes.

abstract: Sacyr Vallehermoso, a Spanish construction company, bid 9.75 billion euros ($13.26 billion) to take over Eiffage of France, a diversified construction company that built the Eiffel Tower, setting the stage for a cross-border struggle for control of the company. The bid came less than 24 hours after a shareholders’ meeting where Eiffage blocked Sacyr’s request for seats on its board, even though Sacyr holds a 33 percent stake. Sacyr offered 12 of its shares for every five of Eiffage, valuing the stock at 104.69 euros, a 6 percent discount to its closing price Wednesday. Sacyr’s approach pits the builder against Eiffage, which views itself as a venerable part of the French establishment.

abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired former UBS investment banker Joe Jiampietro, marking the latest addition to its financial institutions group. Mr. Jiampietro will join J.P. Morgan in July as a managing director in its banks coverage team, the firm said in an internal memo. Earlier this month, J.P. Morgan recruited Tod Perkins, formerly of HSBC Securities, as a managing director in its financial institutions group. The firm also recently brought in Eric Warmstein, who previously worked at UBS, for the financial institutions group as well.

abstract: Two giants of the private equity business are vying to acquire Alliance Boots in what would be Europe’s largest leveraged buyout ever. Hours after Alliance Boots, the No. 1 drugstore chain in the United Kingdom, agreed to be taken private by its deputy chairman and New York-based Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Terra Firma Capital Partners, the investment firm run by the British financier Guy Hands, raised its bid for the company to about 10.9 billion pounds ($21.8 billion) in hopes of trumping their offer.
lead_paragraph: Two giants of the private equity business are vying to acquire Alliance Boots in what would be Europe’s largest leveraged buyout ever. headline.main: Buyout Firms in $22 Billion Battle for Alliance Boots

abstract: Fidelity Investments said Thursday that one of its top executives was retiring amid a broader reorganization in the upper ranks, leaving unanswered the question of who will succeed 76-year-old Edward C. Johnson III as chairman and chief executive at the mutual fund company. But outsiders say the departure of the executive, Robert L. Reynolds, from the company known for its insularity leaves two women as the likeliest candidates to eventually succeed Mr. Johnson at Fidelity, which has $1.4 trillion in managed assets.

abstract: Chicago Board of Trade parent CBOT Holdings, which is the subject of a takeover battle, reported a 58 percent jump in first-quarter earnings, on a 34 percent upturn in revenues. Net income at the Chicago futures exchange came in at $55.4 million, compared with the $35.1 million the company posted during the same period last year. Revenues were $187.7 million, up from $140.1 million, reflecting “record trading volume and higher average exchange fee rates,” the company noted.

abstract: Movie theater chain AMC Entertainment Inc. set a price range for its planned initial public offering that would yield hefty investment gains to the five private equity firms that control it. AMC, based in Kansas City, Mo., said it expects to offer 39.47 million shares priced between $18 to $20 a share. Assuming a price of $19 a share, the midpoint of the anticipated price range, AMC will have an initial market cap of $2.8 billion.

abstract: For corporate lawyers of a certain age, it seems like the 1980s all over again. Proxy fights, once the exclusive domain of investors like Carl C. Icahn, are on the rise. The primary cause, says The New York Times, is easy to spot: “The resurgence of shareholder activism is a direct result of the growth of hedge funds,” Marc Weingarten, a partner at law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, told The Times.

abstract: H&R Block said Friday that it found a buyer for its subprime lending unit, Option One Mortgage. An affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management will pay a price equal to the value of the tangible net assets less $300 million, or about $970 million. The deal comes amid an increase in defaults among subprime mortgage loans, which are loans made to people with weak credit histories. Cerberus, a hedge fund and private equity firm, is getting the unit at a discount, but some analysts expressed relief Friday that H&R Block was able to unload the unit at all.

abstract: Calpine, the bankrupt power generator, said it had reached a preliminary settlement with a group of bondholders that would eliminate a large group of duplicate claims filed in its bankruptcy case. The settlement, which requires United States bankruptcy court approval, will reduce $12 billion in claims tied to bonds in a Calpine unit to a single claim of $3.5 billion, the company said. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it would seek approval from HSBC Bank, the indenture trustee on the bonds.

Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it would seek approval from HSBC Bank, the indenture trustee on the bonds.

headline.main: Calpine Bondholders Agree to Reduce Claims

abstract: ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by Barclays of Britain in a $91 billion deal that would be the largest financial-services merger in history. abstract: British Airways said it was in discussions with several private equity investors about entering a joint bid for Iberia Líneas Aéreas de España, increasing the chances of a bidding war for the Spanish carrier. The Texas Pacific Group, the American buyout firm, made a $4.6 billion approach for Iberia last month. One person with knowledge of the negotiations, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said British Airways, which already owns a 10 percent stake in Iberia, was considering either joining the Texas Pacific bid or backing a bid from one of two other private equity firms, which were not named. British Airways, which has ruled out a bid on its own, said in a statement that any bidding group in which it was involved would probably “include one or more Spanish partners.”.

abstract: AIRLINE EMPLOYMENT The number of employees working for domestic airlines in February rose 0.2 percent over February 2006, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics. But the increase was not because of hiring by the major carriers. Despite record passenger demand, the network carriers had 2.2 percent fewer workers than the previous February. Instead, regional carriers are adding employees (up 5.9 percent over February 2006) as are low-cost carriers (up 5 percent). Compared with February 2003, the number of employees at the big network carriers declined 23.3 percent, to 262,400, from 342,300. Meanwhile, employment at low-cost carriers rose 8.3 percent, to 71,400, from 65,900, and employment at regional carriers rose 22.4 percent, to 599,000, from 489,000 in 2004. That was the first year regional carriers reported unified employee statistics.

abstract: Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid. Sacyr, based in Madrid, made the hostile bid for Eiffage, the company that built the Eiffel Tower, after Eiffage blocked Sacyr, its largest shareholder, from taking a board seat. Eiffage decided not to cooperate with Sacyr after the pair held 14 rounds of talks. Eiffage said. “None of the meetings allowed the companies to identify a common strategy, synergies or even a road map for future joint projects,” Eiffage said in a statement.

lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 23 — ABN Amro agreed today to be acquired by Barclays for 67 billion euros, or $91 billion, creating one of the world’s largest banks in a carefully crafted deal that reduces — but does not eliminate — the chances of another suitor coming in with a higher bid to buy and break up the bank.

headline.main: ABN Amro to Be Acquired for $91 Billion

abstract: After the object of its desire rejected its $1.2 billion bid, the sneaker maker Foot Locker said it was not ruling out the possibility of raising the price. Foot Locker’s target, Genesco, which makes footwear and accessories, rejected the $46 a share bid Monday saying that it undervalued the company.

abstract: Carrefour, the French retailer, said it had agreed to buy a Brazilian discounter, Atacadão, for about $1.09 billion in a deal that would make it the largest food retailer in Brazil. Atacadão operates 34 discount hypermarkets in Brazil, 17 of which are located in São Paulo state. Atacadão’s property portfolio consists of 2.3 million square feet.

headline.main: Carrefour Buys Brazilian Discounter

abstract: Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid.
lead_paragraph: Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. abstract: A Brazilian iron and steel company, MMX Mineração e Metálicos, plans to sell a large stake in one of its mining projects to the British mining company Anglo American, according to a regulatory filing. According to the preliminary agreement between the two companies, Anglo American will acquire 49 percent of the MMX unit Sistema Minas-Rio for $1.15 billion. Sistema Minas-Rio is the company’s most ambitious mining project, with total investments of more than $2.4 billion.
lead_paragraph: A Brazilian iron and steel company, MMX Mineração e Metálicos, plans to sell a large stake in one of its mining projects to the British mining company Anglo American, according to a regulatory filing. According to the preliminary agreement between the two companies, Anglo American will acquire 49 percent of the MMX unit Sistema Minas-Rio for $1.15 billion. Sistema Minas-Rio is the company’s most ambitious mining project, with total investments of more than $2.4 billion.

headline.main: Anglo American Buying Stake in Brazilian Project

abstract: Carl Icahn and the other investors who pressed MedImmune for a sale are probably quite happy with the result: a $15.2 billion bid from the British drug giant AstraZeneca. At $58 a share, AstraZeneca’s offer is 53 percent above where MedImmune’s stock was trading when the company put itself on the block, according to Jason Zhang, an analyst at Prudential. The bid was far higher than many on Wall Street had expected. Shares of MedImmune, which already announced that it had hired Goldman Sachs to look for potential buyers, surged 18 percent Monday in heavy trading.
lead_paragraph: Carl Icahn and the other investors who pressed MedImmune for a sale are probably quite happy with the result: a $15.2 billion bid from the British drug giant AstraZeneca. At $58 a share, AstraZeneca’s offer is 53 percent above where MedImmune’s stock was trading when the company put itself on the block, according to Jason Zhang, an analyst at Prudential. The bid was far higher than many on Wall Street had expected. Shares of MedImmune, which already announced that it had hired Goldman Sachs to look for potential buyers, surged 18 percent Monday in heavy trading.

headline.main: MedImmune Deal Came With Surprising Price Tag

abstract: Brocade claims its post-merger integration with former rival McData is well under way. abstract: A deal to sell the Chrysler Group likely will get tied up in the upcoming contract negotiations between Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers, according to the Detroit Free Press. abstract: Doug Lowenstein ran the Entertainment Software Association, which represented the videogame business, for more than a dozen years. Now he is the head of the new Private Equity Council, a lobbying group charged with improving the image of buyout firms. What could one job possibly have to do with the other? Mr. Lowenstein says there are indeed parallels between the two industries. His explained the common threads in a keynote speech at this week’s Private Capital Symposium in New York, sponsored by The Deal.

abstract: ABC News announced today that it had failed to reach a contract extension with Rosie O’Donnell.
snippet: ABC News announced today that it had failed to reach a contract extension with Rosie O’Donnell.
lead_paragraph: Rosie O’Donnell, who raised both the profile and ratings of “The View” this season by using it as a forum for her rants on the Iraq war, Donald Trump, Oprah Winfrey and even her own castmates, will leave the show in June after failing to reach a contract extension, she announced on the program this morning.

headline.main: Rosie O’Donnell to Leave ‘The View’ in June

abstract: Klaus Kleinfeld’s future was left hanging as the company’s supervisory board wavered over the extension of his contract.

abstract: After 20 years of failed development efforts, buildings are finally going up on Chicago’s long-vacant Block 37.

abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s private equity arm, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, agreed to buy a polymer products maker, Myers Industries for about $1.07 billion, including debt, Myers said Tuesday. Goldman is paying $22.50 per Myers share, a 5 percent premium over Myers’ closing price Monday, valuing the company at about $790 million. The deal also includes about $276 million in debt.

abstract: Cinemark Holdings, the theater chain, failed to wow the critics in its first day of trading Tuesday following its $532 million initial public offering. The company, backed by the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, sold 28 million shares at $19 a share, the top end of its expected price range. But the stock drifted after the debut, trading down as much as 6 percent during the day, to close flat at $18.91.

abstract: Wealthy investors say they are no better than anyone else at finding the world’s best hedge funds, those loosely regulated portfolios that can enrich the people who run them and those who invest in them. abstract: Locked in a proxy fight with its biggest shareholder, a French car parts maker, Valeo said it was open to offers by several private equity firms, Reuters reported. abstract: Carl Icahn is on a roll. Building on a string of successful efforts to push for change at various companies, the billionaire financier has won the endorsement of an influential advisory firm in his face-off with Motorola. Institutional Shareholder Services, which gives voting recommendations to institutional investors, on Wednesday urged the cellphone company’s shareholders to elect Mr. Icahn as a director — despite Motorola’s ardent desire to keep him out of the boardroom.

abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? abstract: If Lee Iacocca, the legendary former chief of Chrysler, has a guess about which bidder will win his old company, he’s keeping it to himself. “Who knows?” was his diplomatic response to Fortune when asked about the auction for the automaker. abstract: In this week’s report on “public policy concerns” surrounding the buyout boom, the Service Employees International Union spent a considerable amount of time bashing the buyout of Warner Music Group, which a group of private equity investors acquired from Time Warner in 2004 and partially sold to the public 18 months later. The union, which has been raising questions about the benefits of private equity deals to workers and investors, wrote that Warner Music’s new owners “hollowed out a once-proud music company, harming its image in the music industry and potentially reducing its long-term value.”

abstract: Canada will ban inefficient light bulbs within five years, the natural resources minister, Gary Lunn, said. While that will remove traditional incandescent bulbs from store shelves, it may also affect other technologies, like bulbs filled with halogen gas.

The two firms announced Thursday that they are teaming up on an $8 billion deal to take Harman International Industries private, an alliance that would seem to undercut the notion, making the rounds on some Web sites of late, that Kohlberg felt threatened by Goldman’s well-funded private equity arm.

abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the giant pharmaceutical company that has long been the subject of takeover chatter, said Thursday it named James Cornelius to be its chief executive officer until 2009. Mr. Cornelius has been serving as Bristol-Myers’s interim chief executive since September, when his predecessor was pushed out in what was widely seen as a tacit admission that the drugmaker was on the block. The company’s decision to make Mr. Cornelius its long-term chief could quell rumors that Bristol-Myers is heading for a sale, although some analysts were doubtful on that front on Thursday. “I don’t think this is going to end speculation about the company’s independence,” one analyst told Bloomberg News.
lead_paragraph: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the giant pharmaceutical company that has long been the subject of takeover chatter, said Thursday it named James Cornelius to be its chief executive officer until 2009. Mr. Cornelius has been serving as Bristol-Myers’s interim chief executive since September, when his predecessor was pushed out in what was widely seen as a tacit admission that the drugmaker was on the block. The company’s decision to make Mr. Cornelius its long-term chief could quell rumors that Bristol-Myers is heading for a sale, although some analysts were doubtful on that front on Thursday. “I don’t think this is going to end speculation about the company’s independence,” one analyst told Bloomberg News.

headline.main: Will Bristol’s C.E.O. Move Douse Takeover Talk?

abstract: Among the details of Thursday’s $8 billion deal for Harman International Industries, one leaped out: Shareholders in Harman, which makes speakers and radios, could end up with an exceptionally large stake in the company once it goes private. Such a provision, known as stub equity, is relatively rare in dealmaking in the United States. But if buyouts keep getting bigger and public shareholders grow more resistant to approaches from private equity funds, it would not be surprising to see stub equity crop up more often.

abstract: Last week, BlackBerry addicts across the country suffered through (or secretly enjoyed) a mobile e-mail blackout. This week, the ValleyWag blog highlighted the opposite problem: People who get so much electronic correspondence that they declare “e-mail bankruptcy.” It seems to be especially common among the Silicon Valley and venture capital set. ValleyWag identifies several entrepreneurs and tech luminaries who have found that their inboxes were so hopelessly overstocked that they needed to wipe the slate clean. Copyright lawyer and Stanfard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig, a frequent writer about technology issues, famously did it in 2004. And on Monday, Fred Wilson, a partner at Union Square Ventures, did much the same on his blog, A VC.

abstract: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., who led an aggressive acquisition strategy that built AT&T into the world’s largest telephone company, said Friday he will retire as AT&T’s chairman and chief executive on June 3. The announcement comes just a few months after AT&T completed its $86 billion purchase of BellSouth, which was the largest deal of 2006. Mr. Whitacre will be succeeded by Randall L. Stephenson, currently the company’s chief operating officer, who is expected to focus on execution and integration at the company, The New York Times’s Matt Richtel reported. Investors and analysts said they were not surprised by the change in command.
lead_paragraph: Edward E. lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is the most undervalued of the five major United States investment banks, but all of their stocks are good investments, James Cramer, the former hedge fund manager and host of CNBC’s “Mad Money,” wrote in his column in New York magazine. They also have lucrative asset management arms as well as in-house hedge funds and private equity funds.

headline.main: Cramer Sees Gold in Investment-Bank Stocks

abstract: Eni, the European oil company, agreed to buy Dominion Resources‘ exploration and production assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $4.8 billion to triple its output from the region. The purchase will raise Eni’s production in the Gulf to 110,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day by the second half of 2007, from 36,000 barrels a day now, the Rome-based company said Monday.

abstract: More than half of the 100 top-grossing law firms in the United States had profits per equity partner of $1 million or more last year, according to American Lawyer. It was the first time that more than half the Am Law 100 has cracked the $1 million mark in profits per partner, the magazine said. At more than $4.4 million per partner, Washington-based Wiley Rein ranked first, thanks to $245 million in fees it earned for its work on the settlement of patent litigation between NTP and Blackberry maker Research in Motion. It was followed by Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and Cravath Swaine & Moore, both of which pulled in more than $3 million per partner, American Lawyer said.

abstract: As with most things on Wall Street, last week’s surge in Amazon.com‘s stock created some big winners and big losers. In the winners’ column: Bill Miller, the mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason whose legendary 15-year streak of beating the S&P 500 ended last year when some of his value fund’s top stock picks — including Amazon — failed to pay off. As recently as January, Mr. Miller doggedly defended his Amazon pick, writing in a letter to shareholders of his fund that “investors wrongly believe today’s low operating margins [at Amazon] are going to be the norm for years.”
lead_paragraph: As with most things on Wall Street, last week’s surge in Amazon.com‘s stock created some big winners and big losers. In the winners’ column: Bill Miller, the mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason whose legendary 15-year streak of beating the S&P 500 ended last year when some of his value fund’s top stock picks — including Amazon — failed to pay off. As recently as January, Mr. Miller doggedly defended his Amazon pick, writing in a letter to shareholders of his fund that “investors wrongly believe today’s low operating margins [at Amazon] are going to be the norm for years.”

headline.main: Amazon Giveth and Taketh Away

abstract: In 1996, Congress passed a minimum-wage bill with a provision to help small companies set up employee stock ownership plans. Eleven years later, the real estate mogul Samuel Zell is using that provision to the utmost in his buyout of the newspaper company Tribune, which creates an entity that is shielded for years from paying income tax. Newsweek’s Allen Sloan sees some irony at work here. He called up John Breaux, the former United States senator who sponsored the 1996 provision, to ask him about the Tribune deal, and Mr. Breaux said: “I wanted to encourage employee ownership. I wasn’t trying to encourage tax avoidance.”
lead_paragraph: In 1996, Congress passed a minimum-wage bill with a provision to help small companies set up employee stock ownership plans. Eleven years later, the real estate mogul Samuel Zell is using that provision to the utmost in his buyout of the newspaper company Tribune, which creates an entity that is shielded for years from paying income tax. Newsweek’s Allen Sloan sees some irony at work here. He called up John Breaux, the former United States senator who sponsored the 1996 provision, to ask him about the Tribune deal, and Mr. Breaux said: “I wanted to encourage employee ownership. I wasn’t trying to encourage tax avoidance.”

headline.main: Of Taxes, Tribune and a Real Estate Magnate

abstract: Andrew Braccia, who had been vice president of consumer Web search at the Internet giant Yahoo, has apparently caught the venture capital bug. Mr. Braccia is joining Accel Partners, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm whose investments include the social-networking site Facebook and the mobile ad network AdMob. Accel said Monday that Mr. Braccia will help it look for new investments in consumer Internet and software companies, with a focus on search, digital media and online advertising.

abstract: There was a big reaction (both in the markets and on DealBook) to Friday’s report on General Electric from analysts at Citigroup, who suggested that a partial breakup of the conglomerate could help its stock break out of its multiyear rut.
